Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this research is to develop a new class of reconfigurable flat optical components that are able to dynamically mold optical wavefronts into arbitrary shapes with subwavelength resolution and fast speed. It focuses on the technologically important mid-infrared spectral range (wavelength 2-30?√ùm), which is uniquely positioned to solve a number of important issues in security, health, and environment. The approach is to use active medium such as graphene, which has tunable optical conductivity in the mid-infrared, to shift the resonance of plasmonic antennas, leading to large and controllable changes to the amplitude and phase of the scattered light. Flat optical components will be created by assembling arrays of tunable plasmonic antennas.
The intellectual merit of this research is that it addresses the fundamental problem of optical modulation: how to obtain considerable and tunable changes to the amplitude and phase of light, given a certain material perturbation.
The broader impacts of this program lie in education, outreach, and implication for mid-infrared technology. The program provides unique educational opportunities in device design, modeling, fabrication and characterization for students of all levels through lab training and research. The program will also promote a collaborative effort between scientists and artists in producing artistic illustrations of scientific discoveries that are more accessible to the general public. The device prototypes developed in this program will have great promise for a variety of applications, such as mid-infrared light ranging and detection, free-space communication, security screening, and biomedical imaging.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual merit: The main goal of this project is to develop a new class of flat optical devices that are based on 1D or 2D designer optical structures, called “metasurfaces”) and are able to control light waves propagating in free space and in optical waveguides. Key scientific discoveries made with the support of this award include: (1) Fundamental understanding of the interaction between light and structured materials in the subwavelength level, in particular, strategies to utilize the degree of freedom in the geometry of “meta-units” (building blocks of metasurfaces) to control more than one properties of light completely and independently (e.g., phase, amplitude, polarization of light waves at multiple wavelengths or over a continuous spectrum of light). (2) Fundamental understanding of utilizing the collective effects of 2D and 1D arrays of meta-units to control light propagation in free space and in optical waveguides. (3) Fundamental understanding of how to integrate actively tunable materials (i.e., materials with tunable refractive indices) with passive metasurface structures to maximize optical tuning, which is critical to realize optical modulators and other active photonic devices.

For centuries people have been relying on light propagation in bulky optical materials to build optical devices, such as lenses, wave plates, and holograms. Various projects supported by the award have laid down a foundation for a new class of high-performance flat photonic devices that can be fabricated with high throughput, high yield and low cost by planar fabrication techniques developed by the integrated circuit industry.

Broader impacts: The PI accomplished many activities of education, outreach and technology transfer under the support of this award. The program provides a comprehensive training for graduate students in materials characterization, full-wave simulations, and device design, fabrication and testing, using state of the art computation, characterization and cleanroom facilities. One graduate student (Zhaoyi Li) has been primarily supported by the award, and another three graduate students (Adam Overvig, Sajan Shrestha and Norman Nan Shi) haven been partially supported by the award. Zhaoyi has published three first author papers (Applied Physics Letters, Advanced Materials and Nature Nanotechnology); he has successfully defended his PhD thesis and is now a postdoc researcher at Harvard. Norman has published a first author paper in Science; Adam, Sajan and Norman all have notable work supported by the award under peer review. In addition, a Columbia undergraduate Isabel Baransky has been supported by the award to conduct summer research on photonic device designs in the lab. The PI has incorporated selected results and discoveries made with the support of this award into the courses he teaches: Modern Optics and Laser Physics. To support student participation of science and technology programs in his local community, the PI served as a judge for the Tri County Science & Technology Fair, organized by the Science Teacher’s Association of New York State in 2015. In addition, the PI taught several classes of preschool children at Les Enfants Preschool, Fort Lee, New Jersey, about the biology of butterflies and moths in 2016 and 2017 (Fig. 1).

 

The device prototypes developed in this program have great promise for a variety of applications, such as mid-IR light ranging and detection (LIDAR), on-chip sensors, flat lenses and holograms, planar optical modulators, variable emissivity coatings, and radiative cooling coatings and fabrics. The program has yielded six technological inventions in the form of provisional patents and PCT patent applications.

 

Highlights of outcomes of this award include:

1. We experimentally demonstrated for the first time achromatic flat lenses that work in the transmission mode for any arbitrary state of incident polarization with focusing efficiencies up to 50% (Fig. 2).

 

2. We experimentally demonstrated for the first time all-dielectric metasurface holograms to generate two- and three-dimensional holographic objects with realistic surface textures.

 

3. We experimentally demonstrated small-footprint and broadband integrated photonic devices based on gradient metasurface structures. This work was published in Li, Yu et al. Nature Nanotechnology 12, 675 (2017) (Fig. 3).

 

4. We experimentally demonstrated broadband and efficient second-harmonic generation in LiNbO3 waveguides using gradient metasurfaces. This work was published in Wang, Yu et al. Nature Communications 8, 2098 (2017).

 

5. We discovered a new optical phase-transition material SmNiO3 that large modulation of light over the entire visible, near-infrared and mid-infrared spectra. We experimentally demonstrated a few active devices based on SmNiO3 and metasurfaces. This work was published in Li, Yu et al. Advanced Materials 28, 9117 (2016) (Fig. 4).

 

6. We demonstrated that metasurface-based biosensors consisting of gold nano-antenna arrays loaded with graphene can achieve simultaneous high-sensitivity and high-specificity detection of biomolecules (Fig. 5).

 

7. We discovered radiative-cooling nanophotonic structures on the skins of the Saharan silver ants that enable the ants to forage under the extreme temperature conditions in the Saharan desert. This work was published in Shi, Yu et al. Science 349, 298 (2015) (Fig. 6).
